channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: An ‘Old Men’s Club’ Dominates Japan. The Young Just Put Them on Notice.
item.description: Change may come slowly in Japanese society, but social media has offered an outlet for a younger generation stifled by a rigid hierarchy.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.category: Chinese University of Hong Kong, The
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Momoko Nojo, a student at Keio University in Tokyo, and one of the authors of the petition that called for systemic change in the wake of sexist remarks by the president of the Tokyo Olympic organizing committee.

item.title: With Strikes in Syria, Biden Confronts Iran’s Militant Network
item.description: Using a carefully calibrated approach, the president hopes to restrain Iran’s regional militia allies without undercutting efforts to reach a new nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Jane Arraf
item.media:description: President Biden “is kind of putting his first red line,” one analyst said.

item.title: Who is Arora Akanksha, the 34-Year-Old Running for U.N. Secretary General?
item.description: The United Nations auditor, with no diplomatic experience, has declared her candidacy for secretary general — an audacious bid to shake up an organization that she says badly needs it.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: Celeste Sloman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arora Akanksha, 34, who has announced her candidacy for U.N. secretary general.

item.title: Amid Slow Vaccine Deliveries, Desperate E.U. Nations Hunt for More
item.description: Countries eager to augment the troubled E.U. buying program are eyeing offers from each other, from Russia and China, and from private brokers, some of whom are fraudsters.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: A patient receiving a coronavirus vaccine in Gdansk, Poland, last month. The country gave up a chunk of its expected Moderna vaccine quota, reasoning that it would not come soon enough to make much difference.

item.title: Shamima Begum Loses Effort to Return to U.K. in Fight for Citizenship
item.description: The British woman, 21, who joined the Islamic State when she was 15, has sought her release from a detention camp in Syria to challenge a decision to strip her of her citizenship.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Laura Lean/WPA Pool, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph showing Shamima Begum when she was 15.

item.title: Biden Orders Airstrikes in Syria Targeting Iran-Backed Militias
item.description: President Biden ordered retaliatory strikes against the militias whose attacks in Erbil this month killed one civilian contractor and wounded a U.S. service member.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The airstrikes authorized by President Biden were meant to punish the perpetrators of the rocket attack but not to escalate hostilities with Iran, the Pentagon said.

item.title: Covid-19 Live Updates: F.D.A. Expert Panel Considers Third Vaccine for U.S.
item.description: Canada authorizes the AstraZeneca vaccine. The coronavirus is on course to return, but there’s still time to stop it.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: One Pfizer dose offers robust protection for those who have had Covid-19, studies find.
item.description: Two new pieces of research add strong evidence to the case for giving just a single dose of the Pfizer vaccine to people who have antibodies against the virus.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: A doctor administering the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine in Salisbury, England, last month.

item.title: A Spreadsheet of China's Censorship Shows the Human Toll
item.description: An online spreadsheet with an anonymous minder tabulates Xi Jinping’s crackdown on speech.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: China Central Television, via Associated Press
item.media:description: China Central Television showed footage on Feb. 19 of an honor guard carrying the coffin of a Chinese soldier killed in a June clash between Indian and Chinese troops in the Galwan Valley on the disputed border between China and India.

item.title: Russians Escape North Korea on a Hand-Pushed Railcar
item.description: Russia said some of its diplomats and their family members, including children, had used creative means to leave North Korea, which closed its borders over a year ago because of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Russian Foreign Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image from a video released by Russia’s Foreign Ministry on Thursday showing the group’s journey.

item.title: Harvard Professor's 'Comfort Women' Claims Stir Wake-up Call
item.description: The professor was widely criticized for writing that the women served Japanese troops willingly during World War II. A Korean survivor called the uproar a “blessing in disguise.”
item.dc:creator: Youmi Kim and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Lee Yong-soo, who was forced to serve in a wartime Japanese brothel, next to a statue symbolizing South Korean “comfort women” in Seoul in 2019.

item.title: Boeing 777 Makes an Emergency Landing in Moscow After Engine Warning
item.description: Pilots diverted to an airport in Moscow after an indicator warned of a possible engine failure on the airplane, a week after engines failed on two other Boeing jets.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Boeing 777 plane operated by Rossiya Airlines.

item.title: Hundreds of Nigerian Students Kidnapped, Police Say
item.description: It was the latest in a series of mass kidnappings, often of schoolchildren, in an area where a surge in armed militancy has led to a worsening breakdown of security.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: ‘V.I.P. Immunization’ for the Powerful and Their Cronies Rattles South America
item.description: A wave of corruption scandals is exposing how the powerful and well-connected in South America jumped the line to get vaccines early. Public dismay is turning into anger.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj, Anatoly Kurmanaev, Manuela Andreoni and Daniel Politi
item.media:description: A nurse preparing a dose of the Covid-19 vaccine developed by Sinopharm of China during a health workers vaccination campaign in Lima last week.

item.title: The head of Canada’s largest pension fund steps down after traveling to the U.A.E. to get vaccinated.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Mark Machin, the chief executive of the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, speaks at the Milken Institute Global Conference in Beverly Hills, Calif., in April 2019.

item.title: U.S. Buys 100,000 Doses of an Eli Lilly Antibody Treatment
item.description: The government will pay $210 million for the doses, which Eli Lilly will ship by the end of March.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A trial site for treatments from Regeneron and Eli Lilly in Mesa, Ariz., last summer.

item.title: Harry and Meghan Going Public at a Tough Time for the Royals
item.description: An interview with the prince, a sort of tease before the couple’s interview with Oprah Winfrey next week, came as concerns grow over Prince Philip’s hospital stay.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Harry and Meghan, shown in Sydney, in 2018, cemented their split with the royal family last week.

item.title: Bangladeshi Writer, Detained Over Social Media Posts, Dies in Jail
item.description: The death of Mushtaq Ahmed has renewed alarm about the country’s use of a draconian digital security law to crack down on dissent.
item.dc:creator: Julfikar Ali Manik and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Praying during a protest in Dhaka, Bangladesh, this month in support of Mushtaq Ahmed, a writer who died on Thursday in police custody.

item.title: Canada Authorizes AstraZeneca's Covid Vaccine, the Country's Third
item.description: The addition of a third vaccine may ease the country’s growing dissatisfaction about the sluggish pace of vaccinations.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: A senior receives the coronavirus vaccine in Quebec on Thursday.

item.title: Bolsonaro Rails at Masks as Brazil's Covid Deaths Surge
item.description: The president says that the pandemic precaution can lead to headaches, difficulty concentrating and a “decreased perception of happiness.”
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil at his official office at the Planalto Palace in Brasilia on Wednesday.

item.title: Britain’s Transgender Stand-Ups Find Comedy in a Hostile Climate
item.description: With opposition to transgender issues regularly expressed by mainstream British figures, the country’s trans comedians are often just trying to assert their humanity.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Lauren Fleishman for The New York Times
item.media:description: “If you make someone laugh,” said Jen Ives, a British comedian, “you’re at least showing them that you are a person.”

item.title: Virus Mobilization
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: President Biden marking the milestone of 50 million Covid-19 vaccine shots having been administered in the U.S. yesterday.

item.title: Johnson & Johnson's Vaccine Could Get F.D.A. Green Light on Saturday
item.description: The committee’s vote is expected to occur late Friday afternoon or early evening, and emergency authorization could come as soon as Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland
item.media:description: Empty vials of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine at a hospital in South Africa.

item.title: What Kind of Plane Am I Flying On?
item.description: After engine debris from a Boeing 777-200 rained down on a Denver suburb, some fliers may want to know more about plane safety and maintenance. Here are some answers.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:description: A United Airlines plane flying from Denver to Honolulu returned to Denver International Airport with an engine on fire after it called a Mayday alert on Feb. 20.

item.title: Michael Somare, Papua New Guinea’s ‘Father of the Nation,’ Dies at 84
item.description: Mr. Somare, who played a major role in leading the country to independence from Australia, was its longest-serving prime minister, holding the office three times.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Hakon Mosvold Larsen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Michael Somare, then prime minister of Papua New Guinea, addressing the Climate and Forest Conference in Oslo, Norway, in 2010.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Germany’s hoard of unused vaccine doses.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: A patient receiving the AstraZeneca vaccine in Rostock, Germany, this month.

item.title: At Least Eight Killed in Haiti Prison Break
item.description: One of Haiti’s most powerful gang leaders was among the inmates who fled the prison in Port-au-Prince.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: Recaptured inmates are led by the police outside the Croix-des-Bouquets Civil Prison after an attempted breakout, in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, on Thursday.

item.title: ‘Victim Blaming’ and Sex Education in the Boys’ Club of Australian Politics
item.description: Scott Morrison’s words, critics said, revealed a disturbing sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka

item.title: The Coronavirus Is Plotting a Comeback. Here’s Our Chance to Stop It for Good.
item.description: Many scientists are expecting another rise in infections. But this time the surge will be blunted by vaccines and, hopefully, widespread caution. By summer, Americans may be looking at a return to normal life.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Lyndon French for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lincoln Park in Chicago. Scientists are hopeful, as vaccinations continue and despite the emergence of variants, that we’re past the worst of the pandemic.

item.title: Germans Clamor for Covid Vaccines, but Shun AstraZeneca’s Offering
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of AstraZeneca doses are sitting unopened as many Germans reject the vaccine over fears it is “second-class” compared to the one developed by BioNTech and Pfizer.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: A patient receiving the AstraZeneca vaccine in Rostock, Germany, this month.

item.title: Canadians Try to Solve the Enigma of Hard Butter
item.description: Pandemic inspired baking has helped focus national attention on a burning question: Why does Canadian butter seem so firm?
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Dairy cows feeding at a farm in Ontario, Canada, last year. A palm fat supplement in cow feed may be responsible for the high melting point of some Canadian butters.

item.title: Police in Malta Say Arrests Are Complete in Journalist’s 2017 Murder
item.description: The force’s commissioner said everyone believed to be involved in the car bombing that killed Daphne Caruana Galizia was in custody. But a motive remains unclear.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Photos of the anti-corruption journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia in Valletta, Malta, in 2019.

item.title: Armenia's Prime Minister, Nikol Pashinyan, Warns of an Attempted Coup
item.description: A group of generals called for the resignation of the prime minister, Nikol Pashinyan, in a dispute that has its roots in a humiliating loss in a war last year.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan of Armenia, center, addressing supporters on Thursday during a march through Yerevan, Armenia.

item.title: Canada’s Top Military Officer Steps Aside Amid Investigation
item.description: The inquiry into Adm. Art McDonald comes amid a second, separate investigation into accusations that his predecessor engaged in sexual impropriety.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Chad Hipolito/The Canadian Press via Associated Press
item.media:description: Adm. Art McDonald in Victoria, Canada, in 2016.

item.title: Refugee Who Set Herself on Fire in Greece Is Charged With Arson
item.description: A woman set fire to her tent on the island of Lesbos in a suicide attempt after her family’s relocation to Germany was delayed.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees in a makeshift camp on the Greek island of Lesbos in September.

item.title: Is ‘Avalanche’ the Answer to a 62-Year-Old Russian Mystery Over 9 Deaths?
item.description: Was it U.F.O.s? Yeti? The K.G.B.? The riddle of who or what killed nine young hikers has inspired conspiracy theories for decades. Two scientists now say a natural disaster may be to blame.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: An image of the hiking trip from Jan. 28, 1959. Cameras and film were recovered after the hikers were found.

item.title: Pakistan and India Renew Pledge on Cease-Fire at Troubled Border
item.description: The agreement between the nuclear-armed neighbors to keep a lid on tensions along the so-called Line of Control was welcomed in the region.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood, Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Indian soldiers at the Pakistan border in December. About 5,000 cease-fire violations were recorded between the nations in 2020.

item.title: Pfizer will test a booster shot and develop an adapted vaccine to address variant concerns.
item.description: Pfizer and BioNTech believe their existing vaccine still offers good protection against circulating variants, and see the plan as a way of learning how to deal with a more threatening mutation.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:description: Pfizer and BioNTech see the tests as a way to prepare for a scenario in which a mutation makes the coronavirus resistant to vaccines.

item.title: Nursing Home Deaths Plummet
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A nursing home resident in Brooklyn received a vaccination last month.

item.title: The pandemic has put some governors in the crosshairs. Just ask Gavin Newsom.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:description: Some Californians see Gov. Gavin Newsom’s handling of the pandemic as grounds for a recall campaign.

item.title: Public dismay turns to anger as South American officials jump the line for vaccines.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj, Anatoly Kurmanaev, Manuela Andreoni and Daniel Politi
item.media:description: Juan Carlos Zevallos, Ecuador’s health minister, is accused of funneling the delivery of vaccine doses to a nursing home where his mother lives.

item.title: For Travel, a Sustainable Comeback?
item.description: From a newly certified Whale Heritage Site to scenic byways for electric cars, five new initiatives suggest the travel industry may be envisioning a more responsible future.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: Squealing Children and Noisy Neighbors? There’s a Map for That
item.description: The crowdsourced guide collects anonymous gripes and pins every grievance on an interactive map, creating a record of the irritating sounds and sights of Japan.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Hisako Ueno

item.title: Facebook Takes a Side, Barring Myanmar Military After Coup
item.description: The move puts the social network squarely on the side of Myanmar’s pro-democracy movement after years of criticism over how the military has used the site.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Mike Isaac, David E. Sanger and Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A global vaccine-sharing program begins.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The first shipment of Covid-19 vaccines distributed by Covax arrived at Kotoka International Airport in Accra, Ghana, on Wednesday.

item.title: California has now lost more people to Covid-19 than any other state in the U.S.
item.description: A bleak reminder that the recent progress the state has made against the pandemic may be fragile.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: A Covid-19 victim being placed in a hearse in El Cajon, Calif., in January.

item.title: Facing Roadblocks, Vast Global Vaccination Effort Gets Underway
item.description: An operation to supply billions of coronavirus vaccine doses to poorer countries has started. But as rich countries buy most of the available supply, stark inequalities remain.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: The global vaccine sharing program kicks off.
item.dc:creator: Jillian Rayfield
item.media:description: A worker at the airport in Accra, Ghana. The country has received a shipment of 600,000 vaccine doses.

item.title: On the Front Lines of Diplomacy, but at the Back of the Line for a Vaccine
item.description: State Department officials overseas expressed anger and disappointment that diplomats in Washington were being vaccinated before those in more perilous posts.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: “Until the department is able to provide vaccines to posts like Pristina, the impact of the pandemic to health, welfare and productivity will remain profound,” Philip S. Kosnett, the American ambassador in Pristina, Kosovo, wrote last week.

item.title: A Top Democrat Warns Against a Hasty Withdrawal of U.S. Troops From Afghanistan
item.description: Senator Jack Reed said he favored seeking an extension of the May 1 deadline for withdrawing troops that President Donald Trump and the Taliban negotiated last year.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: American troops in the Helmand Province of Afghanistan in 2019. The United States has 2,500 troops in the country.

item.title: Head of McKinsey, Kevin Sneader, Voted Out as Firm Faces Reckoning on Opioid Crisis
item.description: Partners decided not to keep Kevin Sneader in the top job. Weeks earlier, McKinsey had reached a historic settlement agreement in the U.S. over its advice to drugmakers.
item.dc:creator: Michael Forsythe
item.media:credit: Samir Hussein/Getty Images for The Business of Fashion
item.media:description: Kevin Sneader has served as the consulting firm’s global managing partner since 2018.

item.title: Italian Cliffside Cemetery, and Its Coffins, Carried Away by a Landslide
item.description: Scuba divers are working to retrieve coffins from the sea, but many more are buried under the debris of the landslide.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: A view of the cemetery in Camogli, Italy, after a landslide carried away hundreds of graves.

item.title: The Coronavirus Can Sicken Children in Very Different Ways, New Study Finds
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:description: A child wore a protective mask and gloves in a New York subway station early in the pandemic.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Lesson to Schoolchildren: Love China, No Questions Asked
item.description: Through new lesson plans and expensive publishing projects, the government hopes to teach future generations a curated lesson about the city’s past.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Golden Bauhinia Square, a symbol of Hong Kong’s return from British to Chinese rule in 1997.

item.title: Arrest of Opposition Leader in Georgia Raises Fear of Growing Instability
item.description: Lawmakers from parties aligned against the government have vowed to continue a boycott of Parliament until Nika Melia is released from police custody.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A protest on Tuesday in Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia, after the arrest of Nika Melia, an opposition leader.

item.title: Husband Must Pay Wife $7,700 for Years of Housework, Chinese Court Rules
item.description: Some in China hailed the divorce court case as a breakthrough, but many noted that full-time nannies are paid far more.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: Apartment buildings in Beijing. Women perform an average of two hours and six minutes of housework each day in China, according to the National Bureau of Statistics, compared with 45 minutes for men.

item.title: New York Opens Brooklyn and Queens Vaccine Sites For Hard-Hit Areas
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:description: Outside of Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn on Wednesday. The site will provide vaccines to residents in parts of East New York, Brownsville, Bushwick, East Flatbush, Canarsie and Bedford-Stuyvesant.

item.title: New World Map Tries to Fix Distorted Views of Earth
item.description: You’re going to need some double-sided tape.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Sokol

item.title: F.D.A. Analyses Find Johnson & Johnson Vaccine Works Well
item.description: F.D.A. studies show the shot strongly protects against severe illness and may reduce spread of the virus. But the drugmaker has fallen short of initial production goals.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer, Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:description: Jacqui Dallimore, a research nurse, delivering a shot to a volunteer in the Johnson & Johnson vaccine trial at the Desmond Tutu H.I.V. Foundation Youth Center in Masiphumelele, South Africa, in December.

item.title: No ‘Covid Zero,’ but Normalcy
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Receiving vaccines at a community center in the Bronx this month.
